body.p:
In your issue of February
4th you ha published an editorial article entitled
"the Mouthpiece of American Israelites." As is not
rare with you there is a certain amount of wrath
developed, and you denounce something as being
"a sham and without foundation."

? An editor who desires to enlighten
his readers should endeavor to treat his subjects
with full information and calm judgment, and
there should be still more wisdom in a whole
Board of Editors.

Let, us dispassionately examine whether your
article is really one that ought to have been printed.
The question involved is this: "Shall the Israelites
of the United States be content to leave any corresp-
ondence with the State Department on the subject of
Jewish wrongs in foreign countries to the Board of
Delegates any correspondence with the State Department on the subject of Jewish wrongs in foreign countries or shall every society or union or
individual exercise its their his or her right
undoubted right to address the Secretary of State
on any subject whatever?"

It ought not to be forgotten that the liberty
of government of the United States are not and ought
not to abandon its traditional policy of non-inter-
vention in other nations' affairs for the Jews or any

one else and that nothing more than polite remonstrances
will ever be obtained from our Secretary. That these
may sometimes be useful is true but in the far
greater number of cases they must remain
without practical result. Thence it follows that
there is rarely such support urgency for Jewish
memorials to the State Department as some
excitable editors and others think. And it
follows likewise that the Secretary must not be harassed
by inflammatory excited papers based on the
wildest rumors. The Yet if every one will immediately
proceed to who reads an anti-Semitic telegram
in a newspaper were to ? write a letter to
the Department praying for Governmental interference
with Germany, the result would necessarily be
that the Secretary would do nothing for fear that
would come to look upon some dread all com-
munications upon Jewish wrongs and in order
not to make himself ridiculous in the eyes of
foreign nations would never take action on any
such matter without much addition such an
accumulation of evidence as to which would dispel all doubt,
whereas if the subject is left to one attentive body,
with trustworthy connections abroad, which body
never speaks until it has real knowledge and
then only with the judgment and moderation
born of experience and reflection, no one can
doubt that the representations of such a body will
have real weight.

The Board of Delegates has performed this duty for nearly
a quarter of a century and at first by as an independent
organization and latterly as a committee of the
Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

No man one has questioned that the good sense and
has always characterized, its actions or fidelity
of its proceedings in this respect, and now you until your
paper began its attacks upon the Union, and I
do not even understand you to say that the work
could be better done, but rather that it should be
done by somebody else.

On that point I suppose no one will quarrel
with you least of all the members of the Board of
Delegates. If They will all no doubt cheerfully
make way for any successors that may be appointed.
That however is not what would seem to satisfy
you.
